sectionCopy.name: Clean energy policy
sectionCopy.value:
Technology-specific auctions have been essential for renewables deployment in Peru. In 2008, under decree No. 1002, the government established auctions to contract on-grid renewable capacity every two years. Since then, four auctions have been carried out, resulting in 71 project developments totaling 1.34 GW of biomass, small hydro, solar and wind. Peru also offers priority dispatch to clean energy plants and 20% accelerated depreciation for renewables projects.
Peru held an auction for off-grid solar in November 2014 to contract up to 500,000 off-grid PV systems. Ergon, the only winner, announced that will develop 150,000-200,000 systems by 2034, when the investment contract expires. As of July 2019, Ergon had commissioned nearly 134,000 systems. Peru was among the first countries to hold off-grid energy auctions.

sectionCopy.name: Clean energy investment
sectionCopy.value:
Peru attracted $3.1 billion in clean energy investment from 2010 to 2018. Most of the investments were in small hydro and onshore wind projects, equivalent to 39% and 32%, respectively, of the total. However, from 2016 to 2018, solar attracted most investment, registering $300 million in the period, compared to $200 million in wind. 

Peru saw a peak in investment throughout 2012-2014, mostly led by financing of auction projects. In recent years, clean energy investment in the country has faded, as only $300 million was invested in 2017 and less than $2 million in 2018. The country has received capital from international and national commercial financial institutions, as well as development banks. The biggest lead arrangers are U.S. Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) and European Investment Bank, registering $235 and $213 million on PV and onshore wind.

sectionCopy.name: Power prices and LCOEs
sectionCopy.value: From 2016 to 2018, power prices in Peru rose an average of 10%.  Industrial electricity was the most inflationary, increasing 12%, from $79.71/MWh in 2016 to $89.68/MWh in 2018. Commercial and residential rates were respectively $106.40/MWh and $137.57/MWh in 2016, rising to $117.95/MWh and $150.14/MWh in 2018.  Even after recent increases, Peru's electricity prices rank among the cheapest in Latin America.

sectionCopy.name: Power market
sectionCopy.value:
In 2018, Peru generated 62% of its total 50TWh from renewable sources including large hydro. That source accounted for 51% in 2018, up from 40% in 2016, despite no significant capacity additions. Regarding non-renewable sources, coal and oil saw shrinkage in generation. Coal was responsible for generating only 43GWh in 2018 compared to 674GWh in 2017; oil declined 71% in the same period. 

Peru's installed hydro (small and large), solar, wind and biomass accounts for 43% of the country's 13,052MW of generating capacity. In 2018, 585MW of small hydro was commissioned compared to 472MW in 2017. Solar capacity jumped almost threefold from 2017 (96MW) to 2018 (285MW), and wind increased 54%, 243MW in 2017 to 375MW in 2018.

sectionCopy.name: Doing business
sectionCopy.value:
Ministerio de Energ'a y Minas (MINEM) is responsible for evaluating the need for auctions, and Organismo Supervisor de la Inversión en Energ'a y Miner'a (OSINERGMIN), the power sector regulator, conducts the tenders. A renewable auction expected to be held in 2018 was canceled in April 2017, and no new tender has been announced. MINEM's explanation for the cancellation is that not all projects selected in the previous auction are being developed.

In 10 years, Peru saw its electrification rate spike from 74% to 96%, the biggest increase in Latin America. The progress is due to a rural electrification program, which included an off-grid auction aiming to contract PV systems for isolated regions in the country.

sectionCopy.name: Barriers
sectionCopy.value:
Peru's energy consumption has been stable, with an average of 1% increase in demand over the past two years. There are indications the country is oversupplied with power assets, which would be the main explanation for the hiatus in renewable auctions.

Aside from accelerated depreciation, Peru offers no tax incentives for clean energy, charging 18% of import taxes for common renewable equipment such as wind turbines and PV panels, and it collects a value added tax averaging 16%.
